title: 107_s2070
content: The "Children First Act of 2002" excludes child care from the 5-year limit for families receiving assistance. It also includes an increase in funding for child care. The "Children First Act of 2002" excludes child care from the 5-year limit for families receiving assistance and includes a significant increase in funding for child care, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2003 to 2007. Additionally, there is an amendment to increase the set-aside for child care quality from 4 percent to 12 percent. SEC. 4 amends Section 404(e) of the Social Security Act to clarify the authority of states to use TANF funds for benefits or services. SEC. 5 addresses the applicability of health and safety standards to TANF child care spending. Section 402(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to require certification of procedures ensuring child care providers comply with health and safety standards. This is in relation to the availability of child care for parents required to work. SEC. 6 amends the Social Security Act to include individuals with custody and changes the section number from 6 to 13. SEC. 7 applies reporting rules from the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 to TANF funds used for child care. Section 411(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include reporting rules from the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 for funds used for child care. The Social Security Act is amended to include reporting rules from the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 for funds used for child care, including subsidized child care and food stamps. The effective date for the amendments to the Social Security Act regarding reporting rules for funds used for child care and food stamps is specified in Section 8. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on October 1, 2002, applying to payments under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act for calendar quarters starting on or after that date. State plans requiring legislation to meet the new requirements will not be considered non-compliant solely for not meeting them before. The plan must meet additional requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter following the State legislature's regular session. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session.
